reviewText:
EDIT 03/29/16: Today, I had a lengthy discussion with the creator of bitDungeon+, who has stated that the issues below will be addressed. While he has requested that I not change this review until said fixes go through, I felt it necessary to at least mention that they will be worked on. Stay tuned!

When this game released on Early Access, I was intrigued. I've spent many hours playing bit Dungeon on mobile, and I enjoy bit Dungeon II. bit Dungeon+, however, has fallen so miserably short that I am sincerely tempted to request a refund.

First and foremost, navigating the menu is a game in and of itself, considering there are no prompts to let you know what does what. Multiple keys appear to function as back and forward, yet there are no guides (only humorous" comments like "are you a master or a chicken")
date: so it is not uncommon to find yourself on the wrong difficulty in the wrong mode because you hammer random keys to try to get somewhere. And no
recommended: you cannot check key bindings; accessing the control menu immediately forces you to begin rebinding all keys
hoursPlayed: and will then kick you out of the menu once you have rebound. Speaking of changing settings
voteText: there are NO audio or resolution options; by default
helpfulPercent: the game is set to an unlocked window that may or may not be largely off screen
votesHelpful: and volume is so loud it is recommended you start the game on MUTE and adjust your operating system or speaker volume once in.\n\nOnce in game
commentsCount: no prompts to let you know what does what. You have to remember what you have bound
column16: or hammer keys until you figure it out. The "tutorial" is laughable
column17: stepping you through rooms telling you to "push the attack button" without enlightening you as to what the attack button might be. Out of the tutorial
column19: but only slightly. Accessing the map/menu
column22: lets you see your stats and equipment
column23: though even this is rough as stat numbers bleed over text and become jumbled
column24: and checking equipment is on a spring and bound to your movement keys; be careful
column25: as holding right to check your sword may lead you into the next room unprepared since the movement controls are still active.\n\nSave your money on this one. Spend it on a polished dungeon crawler like Sword of the Stars: The Pit or The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth. If you still really want this game
column26: wait to see if they continue to patch it (or at least fix the horrible grammar and spelling in the stupid menu messages).\n\nTo those coming back to this review
column28: I deleted my old review as I expected it to change since early access. It has: it's gotten worse. And considering these are now my impressions from the "released" game
column29: the "pre-release" flag no longer applies. This should not have left early access in this state."

reviewText:
Edit:Developer is working hard at making updates for the game, and I can already see that there are way less bugs and glitches, there is also a new game mode called Tower of Babel"


Bit Dungeon+ is a roguelike game where you explore an endless dungeon. Fighting bosses and getting the best loot is your top priority. Oh
recommended: that's the most important part.\n\nGameplay: You control your noble knight that tries to save his girlfriend or something like that. Excuses
hoursPlayed: excuses. You and I know that he just wants to kill all the innocent creatures that live peacefully in the dungeon
voteText: then pull all the gold coins and emerald rings out of their bodies
helpfulPercent: because profit. The whole dungeon idea is kinda inspired by The Binding of Isaac and the likes: You have a bunch of rooms that are connected to each other. By using the doorways you can go into another room. Enemies spawn
votesFunny: you go to the next room.\nThere is also a shop where you can buy various potions and chests with random loot. When you are done with your dungeon floor
commentsCount: you go to a conviently marked boss room
column21: and you do it over and over again. The whole idea is good
column22: but it's not really polished. When I was playing the game
column23: I was working on an autopilot: Kill those guys
column26: repeat.\n\nControls: In one word: Unresponsive. Well
column27: at least while playing with a DS3 controller. I had much trouble hitting my enemies
column28: because my character would often face the wrong direction. When you attack
column29: you also stick to the direction you are attacking at for a moment
column30: so you have to get your finger off the trigger
column31: and try to flip your character to face the enemy.\nYou have a shield that you can use to block
column32: but it's so tedious to use that most of the times I let my enemies hit me
column33: rather than playing peek-a-boo for 20 seconds with them. You can also stomp at the ground
column34: it's supposed to stun the enemies for a brief moment
column35: but sometimes they will still move and shoot at you
column36: I don't know if it's a random element
column38: or maybe something else.\n\nGraphics:They are alright. Enemies are not really creative (skeletons
column40: Your Friendly Dungeon Inhabitants) but their pixel sprites are nicely done. I also really liked how different parts of equipment change your appearance
column41: so you can transform yourself from a boring knight in shining armor
column43: or a Grim Reaper (complete with a scythe!)\n\nSound Sound effects are nice
column44: although they get pretty boring after a while. You probably gonna ignore them after some time
column45: because they are not really that interesting. But I liked the music! Enjoyable chiptune
column46: fitting to a dungeon. What I didn't like is that you can't mute it
column47: because no matter how great it is
column48: it would still be nice to listen to some sweet silence without muting my volume in the Windows control panel.\n\nConclusion I'm very sorry
column49: but I can't recommend the game. It has some fun little gimmicks
column50: like stomping on pools of blood lets you leave bloody footprints for a while
column51: and coming back to a cleared room spawns enemies that feast on the poor creatures you have killed just a few moments ago.But it's all just not enough to let me recommend this game.\nIt's fun for a short while
column52: and when you ignore all the control issues and repetition
column53: you could play it for a while longer
column54: but still not longer than a few hours. The game isn't packed with content for the time being
column55: but I can understand that it's in early access
column56: so I guess we'll see if the game evolves into a fun little roguelike
column57: or will it still be like today: An unremarkable game with unresponsive controls and not enough content to keep you amused."

Finally got it to work after another 15 min of trying and 10 min later we were glitched out side a room with only half of the room next to it showing.

reviewText:
bit Dungeon+ is an upgraded version of a Flash game (which is also available on mobile devices) from a few years ago. You may have heard of it or perhaps its sequel, bit Dungeon II, which has been on Steam for a while now. So, how does the first game in the series, armed with a fresh new coat of paint fare?

The BreakdownClearly, this game is inspired by quite a few popular titles, many of which are also on Steam. Games like The Legend of Zelda, Diablo, The Binding of Isaac, and even perhaps Dark Souls have inspired bit Dungeon. The game plays most closely to Zelda, but elements from the other games I mentioned are definitely present: randomized loot, randomized dungeon layouts, and (somewhat) slow-paced combat along with some giant bosses. bit Dungeon is played from an overhead perspective like most roguelikes out there, but it definitely differs in one major aspect: it feels more like an arcade game than something lengthier that might pop up in Steam's  Rogue-like" tag section.

A standard playthrough consists of the player progressing through a randomized dungeon
recommended: using melee weapons or magic (both are viable)
hoursPlayed: and eventually fighting a boss. After defeating it
voteText: you'll progress to the next floor of the dungeon. There's also randomized loot to be found all over the place
helpfulPercent: along with coins that you can use on shops that are hidden behind certain walls.\n\nThe game is entirely beatable in less than an hour
votesHelpful: yet it's challenging enough to keep you coming back for multiple tries before you can finally manage to beat it. Personally
votesTotal: it took me a decent amount of attempts to even manage to beat it on Easy
votesFunny: which I managed to do with ease once I had acquired some nice gear. Speaking of gear
commentsCount: there's a fair amount of variety in gear types
column16: or at least gear stats and appearance. There's 8 different rarities of gear (based on the color of the item)
column17: though unfortunately in reality every weapon and piece of armor feels and plays the same as all the rest. They may cosmetically appear to be different
column18: but none of the items really "feel" different from one another - they just look that way.\n\nThe enemies are a bit lacking in variety as well. Sure
column20: but they all generally "feel" the same. They all shoot out a small wave-shaped attack (it's hard to describe) at you
column21: though some of them have ranged attacks while others can only attack you up close. Even if the enemies may all look fairly varied
column22: they all functionally only fit into a few categories: melee
column23: invisible (or rather cloaked) melee and ranged. Sometimes the game randomly spawns giant enemies
column24: which are stronger and thus more challenging
column25: which does admittedly add to the fun. The bosses play similarly to these larger enemies
column26: so they're at least pretty fun even if the generic enemies get a bit repetitive after a while.\n\nProbably my biggest complaint with the game is how unpolished it feels. There's a tutorial
column27: but besides a few helpful tips
column28: like how charging an attack will give you a bit of temporary invulnerability
column29: the game doesn't help you out much. For example
column30: in one situation I was stunned by an enemy while a "PUSH!" message repeatedly popped up above my character. I mashed buttons and moved the joysticks around
column31: but I had no clue how to "PUSH!" so I simply had to restart the game. Another example - items have stats
column32: but some of them are utterly confusing; what's the difference between "armor" and "defend"
column33: and what the hell is "proc" or "chop"? The game also doesn't bother to explain what its story is about unless you read the store page
column34: which was a bit amusing to me when I reached the end of the game
column35: only to find my supposed "loved one". It doesn't help that there's a few typos and a decent amount of grammatical errors present as well.\n\nIn terms of bugs or glitches
column37: and that involved me moving through a door
column38: only for it to glitch out and leave me in the entranceway. There was some rats in the room that then swarmed around me (without damaging me) and pushed me into a corner. I eventually killed them and moved on
column39: but from there onwards the game only showed the bottom half of each room
column40: which was pretty odd.\n\nDespite all these complaints
column42: I still enjoyed my time with bit Dungeon+. Is it worth $5? Well
column43: that depends on your personal taste in games and how fine you would be with all the negative aspects of the game that I mentioned earlier. Personally though
column44: for $1-$3 I think that this game would be pretty decent; with some patches (which the developer has frequently been releasing anyway) I think this game has the potential to be really good. The pixel art is lovely
column45: and the enemy designs are pretty creative. The bosses are quite fun to battle
column46: and the game can get fairly difficult at times. I personally died a lot even on easy mode. And hey - the game has co-op support too!\n\nProsFun
column47: challenging roguelike gameplay with an arcade feel to it (randomized loot
column49:
and only 1 life to beat the game!)
Local co-op support (I didn't test it so I can't vouch for its quality)
Controller support
Superb pixel art and enemy/boss designs
3 difficulty settings: Easy
column51: and Hell (along with an extra timed mode)\nCharacter customization to an extent (place items you've found on previous runs on your characters
column52:
though they are purely cosmetic)
Multiple endings
Steam achievements
ConsPretty short for a complete run - takes about an hour or less.
Weapons function in the same way; no variety whatsoever there.
Enemies are also pretty limited in terms of functional variety (they're either melee
column54: or use ranged attacks).\nThe game is extremely lacking in regards to informing the player about a lot of things
column55: whether related to game mechanics or the story itself.\nSome typos
column57: and glitches are present.\nThe music is generally forgettable and gets pretty repetitive after a while.\nThe options menu lacks resolution options or volume sliders
column58: though it does have support for rebindable keys and different languages.\nConclusionAll in all
column59: bit Dungeon+ is somewhat of an unpolished gem. It's covered in dirt and soot
column60: but underneath all that grime is a great game. Sure
column62: but the base game is still quite fun
column63:
and for that I believe it deserves a recommendation.


Final Verdict: 6/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

bit Dungeon+ is a Roguelike RPG with Diablo and Zelda-like elements.
Even in Early Access, it's actually playable. You can do normal stuff with almost no problems, however there are some flawed bugs inside the game.

1) Stamina doesn't recover unless you drink a potion for that. Same goes for Health
2) The colliders are all over the place, you can enter another dungeon through a wall.
3) The loot drops are buggy, you can only open them if you hit" them from the front side. and if you find a loot crate that's for example "Mythical grade" and you have a "Normal grade" in your inventory
date:
you will equip the Mythical one but still the loot crate will show that it's a Mythical grade crate.
and much more....

Anyhow
recommended: This game has Multiplayer (Local couch Co-op to be exact). It's relatively fun to play it with a friend. However
hoursPlayed: you can revive your friend as many times as you want. The person who got the key to unlock the next dungeon is the only person that can open the gate and pass through it. Even after the gate's been opened and the user wishes to return through that specific gate
voteText: Only the person who has used the key can pass through.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: The game's not recommended right now but maybe after an update or two
votesHelpful: it will be a good and addictive game.\n\nEDIT #1: The shop system seems to have been fixed. Good job dev."

reviewText:
I've played bit Dungeon II (Steam version) and bitDungeon (Flash web version) before playing this game. Although this may be their latest game and I do like it, it is not better and may in fact be worse than the other two games in its current state.

The good:
+ It still keeps the roguelike, adventure and dark world pixel-art elements which I like.
+ The game controls somewhat better than the first two games.
+ Co-op mode has been added.

The bad:
- I feel like the character's movement speed is extremely slow. This is very annoying when you go the wrong way in dungeons.
- The game freezes a bit when the character moves to a new room.
- The game becomes competitive after a while with all monsters having same kind of magic attack.
- After about an hour of gameplay I started meeting the same monsters again and again that were just stronger and not new.
- I think I found a bug with the purple dog dancing after death (WTF, but its kinda funny to watch)

The game is still being worked on, and updated. So we'll see, hope it can be better.

reviewText:
bit Dungeon + is a rogue like and dungeon crawler game with a big world to explore.

This is the another chapter of the saga but this time there is no story behind.

This game is a kind of mix between Gaunlet and Zelda that remembers The Binding of Isaac.

You start in different point of a dungeon and then, you must kill monsters and monsters and monsters and more monsters to level up and get better and better equipment.

There a lot of kind of monsters, little bosses and big bosses to fight and a lot of lots to collect.

You could collect black coins dropped by monsters to use in some places to buy weapons or you could be a lucky man and find the great ones in dungeons or hidden by rocks or other sort of objects.

Dungeons are random but this time you have a map and detailed stats of your attributes and inventory.

The character is easy to control using four keys to move the avatar, one key to hit, another to use the shield and another one to cast spells.

You can play alone or with a friend in the same computer, or try a new mode call Babel's Tower (I don't know what objective is behind but you must kill as monsters as you can until time is over)

Music and sound are quite normal but there is no way to increase or reduce the volume so it turns annoying after two hours.

There is no way to change the resolution, and if you resize the window, the game doesn't fit so well.

It has achievements but not trading cards , I encourage to developers to add them in next releases.

Developers must improve or correct some things but you can play it a couple of hours if you like this kind of games.

PS: Thanks to Shade00

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PARAGRAPH WARNING. Yes, I have a lot to say.

I recommend ONLY if you want to see an unplayable game turn into something (potentially) cool.
Decent idea, but right now awful execution.
If you purchase this game right now and expect fun, you're in for a bad time. Details below.

I'll just say right now that, while the makers of the game aren't primarily English-speakers, it looks pretty bad to have so many spelling and grammatical errors. Get those fixed.

It's a very simple hack-and-slash thing, playing similarly to Binding of Isaac and the original Zelda.
Go through randomized dungeons and hit monsters in each room until they die. Stat-giving equipment is all over the place.

==BASIC GAMEPLAY & INTERFACE==
You're a knight with a basic melee weapon and a shield. That's currently the only starting class. You have avatar sets, but they are entirely cosmetic; that greatsword is gonna swing identically to that scythe.

You have an attack button, a magic button, and a block button (Default A S and D). That last one is important, because timing to block enemy attacks will keep you from otherwise requiring trades. A single hit can just chip at your health, but you are in rooms with three to like twenty enemies at once, and they're all attacking on their own patterns, so if you never touch that shield you're going to be dead in three rooms.

Kiting around and blocking effectively is key to getting hits in without taking damage. It's definitely trying to feel like a top-down Souls game -- a concept that is entirely responsible for keeping me around.

Unnfortunately, having three buttons doesn't mean the game is immediately accessible. Thanks to an almost complete lack of interface or instructions, I didn't even understand that I had a block button. The launch options window says 'Fire 1' 'Fire 2' and 'Fire 3'. Ignore these completely, because there's an in-game options menu for that. It says 'Controllers' but it really means 'Controls'.

They don't even have a setting to rebind Up Down Left and Right, opting to have default-blank 'Vertical' and 'Horizontal' axes. Just ignore those input settings.

Oh, don't set anything to Z, either, because that's the debug mode key for spawning a random chest, it seems.

Yes, this executable is for DEBUGGING.

==GAME FEEL & CONTROL BUGS==
The controls are meant to be a little bit clunky and require thought to timing, but the stiffness leads to exasperation more than anything. You will often find yourself stuck swinging in the wrong direction despite holding down another direction's key. If you're close enough to an enemy, you might not even be able to turn, because it seems as though turning is stopped any time movement is halted. This doesn't happen on walls because they are pushing you back instead of restricting movement entirely.

There is a completely unnecessarry delay to most actions. It's caused me to wonder if my keyboard was broken multiple times. There's a small delay before blocking, but no visual indicator that you need to take time to put up the shield. In many cases, it looks like damage went right through your shield.

==SOUND==
The music and effects themselves are mostly passable. The same dungeon tracks over and over can get pretty annoying, but whatever. Unfortunately, you can't set just the music to 0 and play your own stuff while keeping the sound, because there are no audio options anywhere. The game starts blaring at max and you're forced to change it with the volume slider.



This debug version is nigh-unplayable, making you deal with gameplay bugs and expecting you to know what you're doing. Like I said, if this becomes even a half-playable top-down Soulsish game, I'll be happy I got it.

reviewText: Ever wonder what a love child spawned of The legend of zelda and dark souls would be like, for me it would be the bit dungeon games. I love the concept of the overhead view, but with a dark souls feel. randomized loot drop and an ever increasing difficulty.. no real sense of leveling, but know that you are getting stronger. I get that not everyone is a fan of these types of games, and some won't even bother to give it a shot. Most will look only to the negative reviews, some to the positive, some at the price.\n\nAll i can say is, nobody can play the game for you. If the negative reviews keep you away, how will you know they were right? I have both this game and bit Dungeon ii, and thoroughly enjoy both. But as it is, too each their own.. Try it, what do you really have too lose?

Early Access Review

I didn't play a lot of games like this one before, but just got very impressed with the feeling when controlling the player. It's quick and had a lot of fun killing enemies and exploring rooms.

This retro-feeling is very good, once I left the game on for the music while I was doing some other things.
Graphics, as you can see, look very original and animations are ideal with the flow of the game.

There are a bunch of different enemies, each one with its own behavior and make the game more interesting and not boring.

Although it's in Early Access, I didn't find any big drawback, but developers are very kind and receptive on feedback. So it's a very big plus :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Este juego es mi vida. Hasta el dia de hoy, tenia novia, hijos, familia, y un perro. Lo he dejado todo, y nunca he estado antes tan orgulloso de una decision. Esto es el paradiso, el mejor juego de la historia, del planeta, del universo, el messi de los videojuegos. Si lo llego ha saber antes, hubiese ido a por un mando y una cuenta de Steam nada mas salir de las trompas de falopio de mi madre, para asi descargarme el juego y jugarlo hasta morir. Que graficos, que jugabilidad, que personajes, que trama tan esplendida. Jugar a este juego es como hacer el amor con shakira, pilar rubio y maria patiño juntas. Un ♥♥♥♥♥♥o de dimensiones incalculables. Ahora si me disculpais, voy a hacerle el amor a esta obra de arte hasta el  final de mis dias. Gracias mundo por ser tan maravilloso, gracias mundo por tener cosas tan bellas como esta. No hay palabras que describan esta increible bendicion de dios. Gracias...
